author.bio: Chris Marie Green writes hot contemporary romance (like ‚ÄúBedroomies‚Äù!) plus urban fantasy. She also loves devouring pop culture and avoiding international incidents while traveling.

messages.text: Seasons Greetings, neighbor üëã üéÖ
Just a friendly word from the apartment across the way‚Ä¶
You forgot to close your curtains üò≥
Oh man, Hanna ‚Äî I‚Äôm sorry about that!
I didn‚Äôt realize anyone else was here during holiday break.
My building is deserted. My roommates went home.
Same here.
I think it‚Äôs just you and me.
Thanks so much. You saved me some embarrassment üòå
Imagine if I‚Äôd been completely in the buff!
Hanna leans against the wall near the closed curtains of her window.
She tries NOT to imagine that full image of Max‚Ä¶
Especially since she can‚Äôt stop thinking about her glimpse of him with his shirt off‚Äî
Muscled chest and rock-solid arms‚Ä¶
Tousled dark hair against a handsome square jawline.
She‚Äôs always been curious about her neighbor Max, but now she is even more‚Ä¶
Why the heck is someone like him alone during the holidays?
Doesn‚Äôt he at least have a girlfriend back home to visit?
No problem. Happy Holidays!
LOL. Right. I‚Äôm not very into the holidays.
Who are you ‚Äî Scrooge?
Bah Righteous Humbug üëπ
I notice you didn‚Äôt go home to celebrate the holidays, either.
True, but it‚Äôs not because I dislike them.
She peeks through the crack in her curtains.
When she sees Max standing in front of his window, her heart leaps.
Saw you!
Hanna blushes and moves out of the way.
Why don‚Äôt you just open the curtains?
I‚Äôm dressed now.
Yeah, but I‚Äôm still in my pajamas!
Lord knows I‚Äôve seen a pair of THOSE before.
Well, mine are baggy and flannel and for MY eyes only!
üôÑ
Anyway, to answer your question about winter vacation‚Ä¶
I almost went home with one of my friends but‚Ä¶
What?
I felt like having a quiet holiday break. That‚Äôs all.
Hanna peeks out the curtains again.
Max is still there, dressed in a tee shirt and jeans, his hair carelessly ruffled.
And he still looks SO cute.
Hah ‚Äî I see you‚Äôre not done playing your reindeer games ü¶å ü¶å
Hanna‚Äôs pulse beats double time, but then the timer on her oven goes off.
Gotta go. I‚Äôm making gingerbread men.
Bah humbug.
üëπ
Hanna spends the rest of the evening baking, but she can‚Äôt get her mind off her neighbor‚Ä¶
And sure enough, she‚Äôs back at the window that night, peeking through the curtains again.
Max‚Äôs apartment is dark.
Seeing an opportunity to spread some holiday cheer, she runs over to his door with some cookies.
Then she decides to REALLY get Max into the holiday spirit by opening her curtains to reveal her decorated apartment.
She turns on the TV and waits.
A half hour later
Finally ‚Äî you opened the curtains!
There‚Äôs also a plate of gingerbread men who showed up to watch football with me.
Are you the one I should thank for that?
Yup! Have I won you over to the yuletide side yet?
Good try.
You‚Äôre still resistant even after witnessing my winter wonderland decorations?
When she glances toward Max‚Äôs window, she sees the glow of his own TV.
The light dances on him, where he sits on his couch.
It feels comforting to know that they‚Äôre both watching TV at the same time‚Ä¶
Even a little intimate.
Sorry, but even your amazing decorations won‚Äôt win me over.
üôÅ
They remind me of home and how it‚Äôs snowing there right now.
Why is that such a bad thing?
Max?
Maybe we should just talk about what we‚Äôre watching on TV instead. Deal?
Fair enough. But you won‚Äôt want to know what I‚ÄôM watching.
Since you put it THAT way‚Ä¶
I DEFINITELY do.
It‚Äôs Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.
ü§¶‚Äç
Told ya.
Actually, I used to watch Rudolph when I was a kid.
Whoa‚Ä¶and here I thought you were BORN jaded.
üòè
Aren‚Äôt YOU too old to be watching that movie though?
No! I love Rudolph‚Äôs little red nose and Hermey the elf who just wants to be a dentist!
I watch it every year, mostly because‚Ä¶
Loneliness hits Hanna like an avalanche of snow, leaving her with a burn of longing.
Because‚Ä¶?
No use holding back now.
Watching Rudolph used to be a family tradition.
Dad would hand-make one of the toys from the Island of Misfit Toys for me.
And Mom would hide red bulbs around the house for me to find.
Wow. Your parents sound great.
üòä
But I‚Äôm just wondering‚Ä¶
Why wouldn‚Äôt you want to go home during the holidays if that‚Äôs what‚Äôs waiting for you there?
An ache settles around Hanna‚Äôs heart.
Hanna?
There‚Äôs nothing to go home to anymore, Max.
My parents died in a car accident a couple years ago, so the holidays are‚Ä¶
She hits send because she can‚Äôt finish typing.
Jeez‚Ä¶
I‚Äôm really sorry to hear that.
I shouldn‚Äôt have asked.
It‚Äôs okay. It‚Äôs just that this time of year is harder than most‚Ä¶
Especially since I don‚Äôt have family anywhere else.
As she swallows back the lump in her throat, Max walks to his window.
His body is silhouetted by the glowing light.
I know this won‚Äôt make you feel any better‚Ä¶
But I don‚Äôt have anyone to go home to, either.
You don‚Äôt?
No. My reason for staying here during break isn‚Äôt as awful as yours, but‚Ä¶
Well, last Christmas, my parents had an epic blow out.
My mom was never around much anyway, and she took off to Greece with her newest boyfriend.
And Dad was always just as distant, so when he went to live in Costa Rica.
It wasn‚Äôt a shock.
That doesn‚Äôt mean that it wasn‚Äôt hard.
You‚Ä¶didn‚Äôt want to spend the holidays with either of them this year?
Because of that?
A few seconds pass.
No. I tried to contact both of them this year to get together, but it didn‚Äôt pan out.
But, hey ‚Äî they did send gift cards üéâ
Oh, Max‚Ä¶
Now I can see why you don‚Äôt have the heart for the holidays.
The light from his screen reveals the loneliness on his face.
I wish I had the same heart that you still do.
Even after losing so much, YOU‚ÄôRE still able to see what‚Äôs good about the holidays.
I‚Äôd do anything to get that back.
It seems Max is just as alone as she is during this season of togetherness‚Ä¶
But even with him so close by, they‚Äôre each isolated.
Maybe you CAN get your holiday heart back, Max.
But you have to work at it.
Well, if there‚Äôs anyone who could give me hope, it‚Äôs you.
Max turns off the TV, and his apartment gets cloaked in darkness.
His texts stop. Hanna‚Äôs confused.
Eventually, Hanna turns off her own TV.
She spends a silent night full of loneliness.
When morning comes, she forlornly looks into Max‚Äôs window, expecting to find emptiness.
But what she discovers makes her do a double take‚Äî
Snowflakes, candy canes, and bright lights glimmer back at her.
Max? What‚Äôs happening over there?
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
You got me, Hanna.
I couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about you and your story‚Ä¶
And it suddenly hit me‚Äî
That holiday spirit really isn‚Äôt out of reach, because it lives right across from my apartment.
Hanna presses a hand over her pounding heart.
Really?
Yeah. So I decided to start with some late-night shopping and decorating and‚Ä¶
Well, you‚Äôll see when you open the door.
Still confused, Hanna opens her door to find something waiting on the floor.
A red bulb?
Just like my mom used to hide for me?
üôÇ
You‚Äôll want to check the rest of the hallway for five more.
With a surprised, overwhelmed laugh, Hanna begins to search‚Ä¶
And then laughs even more when she finds the next bulb behind a potted plant.
By the time she finds the last one, she‚Äôs as elated as she used to be with her mom.
I‚Äôm done!
Now there‚Äôs something else waiting at MY door‚Ä¶
At Max‚Äôs, Hanna sees a stuffed beige teddy bear with magic marker dots on its fur‚Ä¶
A makeshift Spotted Elephant from the Island of Misfit Toys?
Joy washes over her as she scoops it into her arms and squeezes it tight.
Then Max opens the door.
Inside his apartment is a winter wonderland.
His green-blue eyes sparkle.
I can‚Äôt believe you did this.
I had to.
Somehow you got me hooked on Christmas songs, gingerbread men, and holiday movies.
I feel‚Ä¶just like I used to.
Max grabs her hands.
Hanna, you made me realize that the season is what WE make of it‚Äî
And instead of keeping all that distance between your window and mine‚Ä¶
I really want to make something of the holidays with YOU.
Because you‚Äôre amazing‚Ä¶
Even after life dealt you a blow, you didn‚Äôt quit.
And that gives me‚Ä¶hope.
Max holds out his hand, inviting her into his festive apartment.
She responds with a joyful laugh.
Happy Holidays, Hanna.
She melts into his smile as he brings her over the threshold‚Ä¶
Into a place of bright, colorful lights‚Ä¶
And the warmth of a beautiful, hopeful new season.
